summary: This is an email chain from July 17, 2008, between U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta and other federal prosecutors regarding court filings by Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Mike Tein. The emails discuss Tein's motion to stay civil litigation, which disclosed that a federal indictment had been prepared and grand jury proceedings had occurred, contradicting previous representations to the court.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Recipient and participant in email chain discussing Epstein's court filings and the contradiction regarding federal prosecution.

persons.name: Mike Tein
persons.context: Filed ex parte and under seal motions to stay civil litigation against Epstein, disclosing that a federal indictment had been prepared and grand jury proceedings occurred.

persons.name: Judge Marra
persons.context: Assigned to all federal civil suits against Epstein, including a suit filed against the United States.

connections.description: Tein filed motions on behalf of Epstein in civil litigation.
Acosta and other prosecutors are discussing Tein's court filings and their implications for the federal case.

events.title: Email Discussion on Epstein Court Filings
events.description: Federal prosecutors exchange emails about motions filed by Epstein's attorney, Mike Tein, which disclosed the existence of a prepared federal indictment and grand jury proceedings.

events.title: Tein Files Motions to Stay Civil Litigation
events.description: Mike Tein files ex parte and under seal motions arguing all civil litigation against Epstein must be stayed because 'the federal criminal action' is still pending, revealing grand jury activity and a prepared indictment.

keyFacts: Epstein's attorney, Mike Tein, filed motions disclosing that a federal indictment had been prepared and grand jury proceedings had occurred.
The motions were filed ex parte and under seal, seeking to stay all civil litigation against Epstein due to the pending federal criminal action.
Prosecutors expressed concern that Tein's filings contradicted previous representations to the court that a federal prosecution was never contemplated.
Judge Marra was assigned to all federal civil suits against Epstein, including a suit against the United States.
